body: Mediation sessions are run by professionals who help you try to reach an agreement without going to court. It isn’t relationship counselling and you don’t have to be in the same room as the other parent.

components.html:
### You might also benefit from


**[The Separated Parents Information Programme](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/parents-and-carers/divorce-and-separation/separated-parents-information-programme/)**

Helps you understand how to put your children first and manage disputes with the other parent. There are similar programmes in Wales and Scotland.

**[Become emotionally ready](https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/parents-and-carers/divorce-and-separation/childs-voice-separation/)**

Emotional readiness is being able to put aside your own feelings and any negative thoughts about the other parent. If you’re emotionally ready you’ll have a better chance of making an agreement that’s in the best interests of your children.

**[Tips on how to communicate with your ex](/edit)**

The Parent Connection offers tips on how to communicate with your ex.

### Other ways to reach an agreement

**[Parenting plan](/edit)**

A written or online plan that you use to prepare, discuss and agree arrangements. It’s not legally binding but it can help you make plans that meet your children's needs.
